[[File:ADvTECH Group.svg|thumb|ADvTECH Group logo]] The '''ADvTECH Group''' is a JSE listed company in South Africa (JSE:ADH).<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://thepienews.com/news/south-africas-advtech-plans-east-africa-expansion/ |title=South Africa's ADvTECH plans East Africa expansion |last=News |first=The PIE |website=thepienews.com |language=en |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> ADvTECH operates within the education and recruitment industries in South Africa and the rest of Africa<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pressreader.com/south-africa/business-day/20180404/281479276977547|title=PressReader.com - Connecting People Through News|website=www.pressreader.com|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref>.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eprop.co.za/commercial-property-news/item/20838-advtech-properties-to-expand-asset-base-to-r6bn-by-2022.html|title=ADvTech Properties to expand asset base to R6bn by 2022 - eProperty News|first=eProperty|last=News|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rnews.co.za/article/17953/academic-excellence-the-secret-to-advtech-schools-learners-ieb-success|title=Academic excellence the secret to ADvTECH schools learners' IEB success|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iol.co.za/business-report/advtech-makes-r344m-interim-profit-on-growing-tertiary-division-10875104|title=Advtech makes R344m interim profit on growing tertiary division - IOL Business Report|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/story/?resource_id=SENSIN_20171215074700_53|title=BusinessLIVE|website=www.businesslive.co.za}}</ref>
ADvTECH is Africa's largest private education provider and<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.inceconnect.co.za/article/advtech-bolsters-east-african-schools|title=ADvTECH bolsters East African schools {{!}} Companies|website=www.inceconnect.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> the holding company of the [[The Independent Institute of Education|Independent Institute of Education]] which operates tertiary education brands including [[Vega (South Africa)|Vega School]], Capsicum Culinary Studio, [[Abbotts Colleges]], [[Varsity College]], Rosebank College, The Business School at [[Varsity College]] and The University of Africa in Zambia.<ref name="businesstech.co.za">{{cite web|url=https://businesstech.co.za/news/business/193542/crawford-schools-owner-advtech-reports-22-rise-in-interim-revenue/|title=Crawford Schools owner Advtech reports 22% rise in interim revenue|publisher=}}</ref>
The group also operates a schools division, under which, brands including Crawford Schools, Trinityhouse,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.trinityhouse.co.za/about-us/|title=About Us {{!}} Christian School {{!}} Trinityhouse|website=www.trinityhouse.co.za|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://roodepoortnorthsider.co.za/228643/trinityhouse-unveils-the-little-falls-high-school/|title=Trinityhouse unveils the Little Falls High School {{!}} Roodepoort Northsider|date=2016-07-25|work=Roodepoort Northsider|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en-US}}</ref> Abbotts College, Maravest, Centurus Colleges and Junior Colleges operate.<ref name="businesstech.co.za"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.advtech.co.za/Pages/About/Education-Brands.aspx|title=Advtech Group {{!}} Education Brands|website=www.advtech.co.za|language=en|access-date=2018-04-18}}</ref>
The current CEO of the ADvTECH Group is Roy J Douglas<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/2017-03-23-private-education-specialist-advtech-hands-in-robust-performance/|title=Private education specialist Advtech hands in robust performance|publisher=}}</ref>
In late 2017 the company discovered a fraud by a financial manager in its schools division.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://businesstech.co.za/news/business/214217/education-group-advtech-comes-clean-on-fraud/ |title=Education group ADvTECH comes clean on fraud |language=en-US |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/companies/2017-12-01-advtech-to-restate-revenue-and-profit-figures-after-it-uncovers-fraud/ |title=Fraud hits Advtech stock |language=en-US |access-date=2018-03-14}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}}

'''Academic Programs International''' ('''API''') is an independent study abroad provider based in the [[United States]]. Its locations include [[Argentina]], [[Bhutan]], [[Chile]], [[China]], [[Costa Rica]], [[Croatia]], [[Cuba]], [[England]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]], [[Ireland]], [[Italy]], [[Mexico]], [[Poland]], [[Portugal]], [[Qatar]], [[Scotland]], [[Spain]], and the [[United Arab Emirates]].
API offers international internships in [[Argentina]], [[Chile]], [[England]], [[Ireland]], and [[Spain]] on which participants have the opportunity to earn college credit.
API procures housing and educational arrangements as well as excursions in each program. A scholarship of $250–1000 is also provided, the amount being partially based on financial need and partially based on the student's merits (essays/recommendations).
==Destinations==
[[Argentina]] * '''[[Buenos Aires]]''' – [[Universidad de Belgrano]], [[Universidad Torcuato di Tella]] * '''[[Mendoza, Argentina|Mendoza]]''' – Universidad de Congresso
[[Bhutan]] * '''[[Thimphu]]''' – [[Royal Thimphu College]]
[[Chile]] * '''[[Valparaíso]]''' – Pontifícia Universidad Católica de Valparaíso, Universidad Técnica Federico Santa María * '''[[Viña del Mar]]''' – Universidad Viña del Mar, Universidad Adolfo Ibáñez
[[China]] * '''[[Beijing]]''' – [[Beijing Normal University]] * '''[[Shanghai]]''' – Xianda College of Economics and Humanities – [[Shanghai International Studies University]]
[[Costa Rica]] * '''[[San Joaquín de Flores]]''' – Instituto San Joaquín de Flores * '''[[San José, Costa Rica|San José]]''' – Universidad Veritas, International Center for Development Studies
[[Cuba]] * '''[[Havana]]''' – [[Universidad de la Habana]]
[[Croatia]] * '''[[Dubrovnik]]''' – [[DIU Libertas International University]]
[[England]] * '''[[Leeds]]''' – [[University of Leeds]] * '''[[London]]''' – [[University of the Arts London]], [[University of Westminster]], [[London School of Economics]], [[School of Oriental and African Studies]], [[University College London]]
[[France]] * '''[[Caen]]''' – Université de Caen, Basse-Normandie * '''[[Grenoble]]''' – Centre Universitaire d'Etudes Francaises, Grenoble École de Management * '''[[Paris]]''' – Université de Paris, Université de Paris VII (Diderot), Université de Paris IX (Dauphine)
[[Germany]] * '''[[Berlin]]''' – FU-BEST, the Berlin European Studies Program of Freie Universität Berlin, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin
[[Hungary]] * '''[[Budapest]]''' – [[Corvinus University of Budapest]]
[[Ireland]] * '''[[Cork (city)|Cork]]''' – [[University College Cork]], [[National University of Ireland]] * '''[[Dublin]]''' – [[Trinity College Dublin]], [[University College Dublin]], [[Maynooth University]] * '''[[Galway]]''' – [[National University of Ireland]], Galway * '''[[Limerick]]''' – [[University of Limerick]]
[[Italy]] * '''[[Florence]]''' – Lorenzo de’ Medici – The Italian International Institute * '''[[Rome]]''' – John Cabot University, Lorenzo de’ Medici – The Italian International Institute * '''[[Taormina]]''' – Babilonia – Center for Italian Language and Culture * '''[[Tuscania]]''' – Lorenzo de’ Medici – The Italian International Institute * '''[[Venice]]''' – Marist College
[[Mexico]] * '''[[Querétaro]]''' – Centro Intercultural de Querétaro
[[Poland]] * '''[[Kraków]]''' – Jagiellonian University of Kraków
[[Portugal]] * '''[[Lisbon]]''' – [[UMass]] in Lisbon,
[[Qatar]] * '''[[Doha]]''' – [[Qatar University]]
[[Scotland]] * '''[[Edinburgh]]''' – Heriot-Watt University * '''[[Stirling]]''' – [[University of Stirling]]
[[Spain]] * '''[[Barcelona]]''' – [[University of Barcelona]], University Autónoma of Barcelona, University Pompeu Fabra, [[ESADE Business School]] * '''[[Bilbao]]''' – [[University of the Basque Country]], [[University of Deusto]] * '''[[Cádiz]]''' – [[University of Cádiz]] * '''[[Granada]]''' – [[University of Granada]] * '''[[Madrid]]''' – [[Complutense University]], [[Suffolk University]], Antonio De Nebrija University, Universidad Francisco de Vitoria * '''[[Salamanca]]''' – [[University of Salamanca]] * '''[[Seville]]''' – [[University of Seville]], Pablo De Olavide University
[[United Arab Emirates]] * '''[[Sharjah (emirate)|Sharjah]]''' – [[American University of Sharjah]]
==Fees== Program prices vary based on location and term, but can hover around $4,000-$7,000 for a summer session, or $8,000-$25,000 for a semester session (check website for current pricing information). Fees for most programs do not vary with how many credit hours are taken in that period, and include many useful services such as housing, meals, travel, medical insurance, etc.
==Excursions== Each program typically offers multiple extracurricular excursions (depending on the selected destination) included in the flat-rate fee. These may include day trips, overnight/weekend trips, or international trips. They last a few days and travel is done with other students in the API group.
==External links== * [http://www.apistudyabroad.com/ Official website]
[[Category:Study_abroad_programs]]

{{Unsourced|date=November 2014}} [[Academic ranks]] in [[Denmark]] are the titles, relative importance and power of professors, researchers, and administrative personnel held in [[academia]].
==Overview== Academic positions at the level of Professor:<ref>http://ufm.dk/lovstof/gaeldende-love-og-regler/uddannelsesinstitutioner/stillingsstruktur-for-videnskabeligt-personale-ved-universiteterne</ref> * ''Professor'' ([[professor]]) * ''Forskningsprofessor'' (research professor) * ''Professor MSO'' (professor with special responsibilities; temporary rank) * ''Forskningsprofessor MSO'' (research professor with special responsibilities; temporary rank)
Academic positions at the level of Associate Professor:<ref>http://ufm.dk/lovstof/gaeldende-love-og-regler/uddannelsesinstitutioner/stillingsstruktur-for-videnskabeligt-personale-ved-universiteterne</ref> * ''Lektor'' (Associate Professor), time traditionally divided as 50-40-10 between teaching, research, and administration * ''Seniorforsker'' (Senior Researcher)
Academic positions at the level of Assistant Professor:<ref>http://ufm.dk/lovstof/gaeldende-love-og-regler/uddannelsesinstitutioner/stillingsstruktur-for-videnskabeligt-personale-ved-universiteterne</ref> * ''Post doc'' ([[Post-doc]]), generally a research position without the possibility of teaching * ''[[Adjunct professor|Adjunkt]]'' (Assistant Professor), usually almost the same teaching/research/administration division as ''lektor'', although sometimes a little more time for research * ''Forsker'' (Researcher)
Academic positions below the level of Assistant Professor:<ref>http://ufm.dk/lovstof/gaeldende-love-og-regler/uddannelsesinstitutioner/stillingsstruktur-for-videnskabeligt-personale-ved-universiteterne</ref> * ''phd studerende'' (PhD Fellow) * ''Forskningsassistent'' (Research Assistant) * ''Undervisningsassistent'' (Assistant Lecturer) * ''Ekstern lektor'' (Part-time Lecturer), requires a master's degree in the subject taught, but not a research degree (PhD or equivalent)
Special positions:<ref>http://ufm.dk/lovstof/gaeldende-love-og-regler/uddannelsesinstitutioner/stillingsstruktur-for-videnskabeligt-personale-ved-universiteterne</ref> * A number of specialised academic positions such as Senior Adviser and Associate Clinical Professor are also in use.
Administrative positions: * ''Rektor'' (rector) * ''Prorektor'', second-ranked official of governance, deputy rector. * ''Dekan'' (dean), head of a faculty (humanities, natural sciences, etc.) * ''Institutleder'' (head of department), head of department (computer science, mathematics, etc.) * ''Studieleder'' (programme director), head of a study programme (business administration, civil engineering, etc.)
==Professorship== In Denmark the word professor is only used for full professors. An associate professor is in Danish called a ''lektor'' and an assistant professor is called an ''adjunkt''. Before promotion to full professorship, one can get a time limited (usually 5 years) post as an MSO (professor med særlige opgaver) or "professor with special responsibilities." The post of professor with special responsibilities involves fixed-term specific functions as well as duties that are otherwise associated with professorships. The qualification requirements correspond to those of ordinary professorships. This position gives time for the school to raise funds for the permanent professorship. An additional step between lektor and full professor is ''[[docent]]''. A docent has the same work as a professor but they do not actively take part in senior administrative duties, such as heading a department. The Danish PhD does not come with a title; only the local docent, after a similar extended thesis to the German docent, brings the right to be addressed as ''doktor''.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox school | name = Al-Thager Model School | native_name= مدارس الثغر النموذجية, | image = | established = 1947 | type = | director = Saud Al Khudaidi | head_name = | head = | head_name2 = | head2 = | city = [[Jeddah]] | country = {{flagicon|Saudi Arabia}} [[Saudi Arabia]] | grades = | gender = [[Single-sex education|All-boys]] | enrollment = | language = | free_label_1 = | free_1 = | publication = | free_label_2 = | free_2 = | motto = | website = [http://www.thghr.com Official website] }}
A [[secondary school]] in [[Jeddah]], [[Saudi Arabia]], the '''Al-Thager Model School''' ({{lang-ar|مدارس الثغر النموذجية}}, the name roughly is "The Haven"<ref name="Coll143">Coll 143</ref>) is a two-story building that used to house both primary and secondary grades, as well as residential dormitories on the second level.
==History== [[Faisal bin Abdul Aziz]] founded the school in [[Taif]] in the early 1950s. In 1964 Faisal opened a large campus for the school in [[Jeddah]], and from that point forward, arranged an annual fund of several million [[Saudi riyal]]s from the national budget. Kamal Adham, Faisal's Turkish father-in-law, traveled to the United Kingdom to meet officials from the government. Adham told the officials that the school ought to be modeled after [[Victoria College (Sudan)|Victoria College]], a school in [[Khartoum]], [[Sudan]] inspired by [[British education]].<ref name="Coll143"/> The [[Government of Saudi Arabia]] provided funds and staff members for the school.<ref name="Coll142">Coll 142</ref> Steve Coll, author of ''The Bin Ladens: An Arabian Family in the American Century'', said that during the 1960s and 1970s Al-Thager "had the reputation of a private enclave for the sons of businessmen and the royal family."<ref name="Coll142143">Coll 142-143</ref> Al-Thager became the most prestigious school in Jeddah.<ref name="CollYoungOsama">Coll, Steve. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20051215085524/http://www.newyorker.com/fact/content/articles/051212fa_fact YOUNG OSAMA]." ''[[The New Yorker Fact]]''. Issue of 2005-12-12. Retrieved on 7 May 2011.</ref>
The school's entrance examinations were open to all Saudis. Some lower class Saudis were granted acceptance and attended the school with wealthier Saudis. Around that era, each graduating class consisted of around 60 boys.<ref name="Coll143"/> During that period many Egyptian and Syrian teachers, who had been involved in dissident Islamic organizations in their home countries, taught at Al-Thager, as many did in other Saudi primary and secondary schools and universities.<ref name="Coll144">Coll 144</ref> Coll said in the 1960s and early 1970s that the school "had a relatively secular flavor."<ref name="CollYoungOsama"/>
Around the early 1970s many Al-Thager students engaged in political debates. One group of students, influenced by [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]], [[President of Egypt]], were in favor of [[Pan-Arab nationalism]]. Another group of students, influenced by the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], were in favor of additional [[Islam]]ic influence in politics in the Arab world.<ref name="Coll147">Coll 147</ref> Coll said that Al-Thager was "a conspicuous example of modernization without secularization."<ref name="Coll153">Coll 153</ref>
==Campus== In the 1960s the school campus was located near downtown [[Jeddah]], with the campus north of Old Jeddah Road. A two story concrete and fieldstone building served as the school's main classroom building. Steve Coll, author of ''The Bin Ladens: An Arabian Family in the American Century'', said that the building was in a "featureless modern style."<ref name="Coll142"/> The school had two classroom wings, one for middle school students and one for high school students. An interior courtyard was located between the wings.<ref name="Coll142"/>
In the 1960s most students were day students and commuted to school. The boarding students and some foreign teachers lived in dormitories on the school's second floor.<ref name="Coll142"/>
In the 1960s Al-Thager was the only school in Jeddah to have [[air conditioning]].<ref name="Coll143"/>
==Curriculum and discipline== Steve Coll, author of ''The Bin Ladens: An Arabian Family in the American Century'', said that in the 1960s and 1970s Al-Thager "prided itself on its modern curicculum" and that it was the only Saudi school that "could even begin to compare itself to a place like" [[Brummana High School]] in [[Brummana]], [[Lebanon]].<ref name="Coll142"/> During that period the school had English instruction provided by many foreign [[English teacher]]s from [[England]] and [[Ireland]].<ref name="Coll143"/> Al-Thager, like other Saudi schools, had religion as a core component in the instruction. At noon, the boys performed ''[[zuhr]]'', the Islamic prayer at noontime.<ref name="Coll143144">Coll 143-144</ref> Each morning, the school prompted boys in a military-style call of order to assemble in rows. Teachers had canes, and disciplined boys by striking their feet.<ref name="Coll143"/>
==Dress code== The students wear western-style school uniforms seen in American and British [[university preparatory school]]s; in most Saudi schools for boys, the students wear [[thobe]]s and cloth headdresses. During the 1960s and 1970s, students wore white oxford shirts with ties, grey trousers, black socks, and black shoes. During winter periods students wore charcoal-coloured blazers.<ref name="Coll143"/>
==Notable alumni== [[Osama bin Laden]] began attending Al-Thager in 1968, either in the fifth or sixth grade.<ref name="Coll142"/> Osama's education at Al-Thager ended in 1976. Former teachers, Brian Fyfield-Shayler and Seamus O’Brien gave an interview to ''[[The New Yorker]]'' in which they claimed that they remembered teaching Osama bin Laden at the school.<ref name="CollYoungOsama"/> Some of Osama's half-brothers were enrolled at Al-Thager.<ref>Coll 151.</ref>
==Sources== * Coll, Steve. ''The Bin Ladens: An Arabian Family in the American Century''. [[New York City]]: [[The Penguin Press]], 2008.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|Saudi Arabia|Schools}} * [http://www.thghr.com/ Al-Thager Model School] {{ar icon}}

[[File:Ang Choulean.jpg|thumbnail]] '''Ang Choulean''' ({{lang-km|[[:km:អាំង ជូលាន|អាំង ជូលាន]]}}) (born 1 January 1949 in Kompong Kleang, [[Siem Reap]]) is a [[Cambodia]]n [[anthropologist]]. He is a professor of historical anthropology at the [[Royal University of Fine Arts]] and formerly the director of the department of culture of [[APSARA]], the Cambodian management authority responsible for protecting the archaeological park of [[Angkor]].
He earned a bachelor's degree in Archaeology in 1974 in Cambodia and a PhD in Anthropology in 1982 in France.<ref>មនុស្ស និងដី បោះពុម្ពផ្សាយដោយវិទ្យាស្ថានរៃយំ</ref>
Ang Choulean was the second [[Khmer people|Khmer]] person win a Grand Prize of [[Fukuoka Prize]] from Japan in 2011 after [[Chheng Phon]] in 1997.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * [http://www.talesofasia.com/cambodia-interviews-AC.htm Interview] * https://www.theguardian.com/world/2001/aug/07/humanities.green * [[:km:អាំង ជូលាន|អាំង ជូលាន]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Anti-Recidivism Coalition |image = |image_border = |size = |caption = |formation = 2013 |type = |headquarters = |location = [[Los Angeles, California]] |membership = |language = |leader_title = Founder |leader_name = [[Scott Budnick (film producer)|Scott Budnick]] |key_people = |num_staff = |budget = |website = {{Official URL|http://www.antirecidivism.org/}} }}
The '''Anti-Recidivism Coalition''' ('''ARC''') is a [[Los Angeles]]-based non-profit organization founded by [[Scott Budnick (film producer)|Scott Budnick]]. ARC is a support network for formerly incarcerated individuals and advocates for [[criminal justice reform]]. ARC’s mission is to reduce [[incarceration]], improve the outcomes of formerly incarcerated individuals, and to build healthier communities.
== History == In 1997, Budnick first became interested in juveniles in prison after reading a ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' article about [[Brandon Hein]] and three other youths who were found guilty of first-degree murder and sentenced to life without the possibility of parole in California even though three of them never touched the weapon.<ref name=mother>{{cite web|last1=Mechanic|first1=Michael|title=Why the Producer of "The Hangover Part III" Spends So Much Time in Prison|url=https://www.motherjones.com/media/2013/05/hangover-part-iii-executive-producer-scott-budnick-california-prison-interview|publisher=Mother Jones|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> Budnick sent the article to a producer who optioned it for a documentary film called ''Reckless Indifference''.<ref name=mother />
In 2003, Budnick began volunteering at the Barry J. Nidorf Juvenile Hall in Sylmar, California.<ref name=mother /> Budnick was a volunteer teacher for a group called [[InsideOUT Writers]].<ref name=Rainey>{{cite web|last1=Rainey|first1=James|title=Resurrection Story Inspires on Prophet's Campaign Trail|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/la-me-c1-prophet-walker-20140421-m-story.html#page=1|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> As of 2014, Budnick still volunteers at the Nidorf Juvenile Hall.<ref name=times>{{cite web|last1=Mehta|first1=Seema|title=For Writers in Juvenile Hall, Sentences Can be Liberating|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/great-reads/la-me-c1-juvenile-hall-writers-20140922-story.html#page=2|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> After this experience and others, Budnick began to tell administrators and politicians about the problems he was seeing in the juvenile justice and criminal justice systems.<ref name=mother /> After the success of Budnick's [[The Hangover]] franchise, Budnick was able to leverage the work he does for incarcerated juveniles.<ref name=mother /> [[Jake Gyllenhaal]] went with Budnick to the Sylmar juvenile detention center, to [[Men's Central Jail]] and out to [[California State Prison, Los Angeles County]].<ref name=mother />
In 2012, Budnick was named California's Volunteer of Year by Governor Jerry Brown for a program he envisioned. After seeing kids desperate to change their lives but unable to because of California law at that time, Budnick and other launched a pilot program out of Los Angeles County where every single kid coming into the prison system—if they are doing the right things on their own—got to go to a place where they could get their high school diploma or GED, go to college classes, learn a trade, and be in self-help programs and substance-abuse programs.<ref name=mother /> In 2013, the program was adopted statewide.<ref name=mother />
== Founding == Budnick began to see many of the kids he worked with—in some of his college programs—come out of prison and going into universities, community colleges, and obtaining employment. Budnick saw a network of ex-offenders and ex-gang-members who were changing their lives. Then, Budnick and others started doing retreats where the formerly incarcerated young people would meet with mentors and lawyers, and eventually formed a private [[Facebook]] page where they organized events and provided support.<ref name=mother />
In 2013, Budnick officially launched the Anti-Recidivism Coalition (ARC), a formal organization of formerly-incarcerated young adults who work to support one another, and that also aims to lower the number of people flowing into the criminal justice system through policy advocacy and community organizing. Budnick said "I started to see that there was not an organization out there that had high-achieving guys coming out of prison who could articulate why hope is important and why kids deserve a second chance and why kids are different from adults."<ref name=mother />
=== Support network === ARC serves as a support network and a connection to services for over one hundred formerly incarcerated individuals. Members must commit to live crime-free, gang-free, drug-free, in school or working, and in service to their community. ARC provides support through mentoring, case management, internship and employment opportunities, regular support network meetings and social outings. Members receive mentoring from professional adult volunteers, known as ARC Allies, and through ARC’s Leadership Council that includes formerly incarcerated youth who are now university graduates, lawyers, engineers, politicians and other successful professionals.{{r|ARC}} ARC host retreats for members of the ARC network.<ref name=mother /><ref name=sunday />
=== Policy advocacy === ARC’s policy reform advocacy is conducted by formerly incarcerated individuals who have successfully transformed their lives.<ref name=ARC>{{cite web|title=Our Work |website=Anti-Recidivism Coalition|url=http://www.antirecidivism.org/our_work|publisher=Anti-Recidivism Coalition|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> In 2014, ARC teamed up with the [[Ford Foundation]] and others to host a [[TEDx]] conference inside [[Ironwood State Prison]] with hundreds in attendance.<ref name=TED>{{cite web|last1=Mechanic|first1=Michael|title=TEDx goes to Prison|url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2014/06/ironwood-state-prison-tedx-richard-branson-scott-budnick-sean-stephenson|publisher=Mother Jones|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> ARC produced a documentary about the event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Watch the 9-min doc of TEDxISP! |url=http://www.antirecidivism.org/tedxironwoodstateprison2014 |publisher=Anti-Recidivism Coalition |accessdate=2 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419212411/http://www.antirecidivism.org/tedxironwoodstateprison2014 |archivedate=19 April 2015 }}</ref> Prophet Walker, a founding member of ARC, was a guest of [[Michelle Obama]]'s at the 2015 State of the Union.<ref name=SOTU>{{cite web|last1=Lee|first1=Kurtis|title=State of the Union: Who are Michelle Obama's guests?|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/politicsnow/la-na-pn-sotu-guests-20150119-htmlstory.html|publisher=LA Times|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> After serving a six-year prison sentence, Walker sought to strengthen the bond between police officers and inner-city residents.<ref name=SOTU /><ref name=IBT>{{cite web|last1=Morrison|first1=Aaron|title=Who is Prophet Walker? Ex-Felon Turned Community Leader Invited To Obama's State Of The Union Address|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/who-prophet-walker-ex-felon-turned-community-leader-invited-obamas-state-union-1789052|publisher=International Business Times|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> ARC's Budnick writes about criminal justice policy for the [[Huffington Post]].<ref name=mark>{{cite web|last1=Budnick|first1=Scott|last2=Levick|first2=Marsha|title=Mark Wahlberg Has a Problem, and He's Not the Only One|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/marsha-levick/mark-wahlberg-has-a-probl_b_6344534.html|publisher=Huff Post|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> ARC successfully advocated for California Senate Bill 260, which guarantees that offenders who received long sentences as juveniles have the opportunity to be considered for parole.<ref name=NBC>{{cite web|last1=Shriver|first1=Maria|title=Producer Scott Budnick On Changing Lanes And Juvenile Justice|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/feature/maria-shriver/producer-scott-budnick-changing-lanes-juvenile-justice-n93566|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref>
In 2015, James Anderson, a formerly incarcerated young man and first founding staff of ARC, spoke alongside [[John Legend]] in [[Sacramento]] about criminal justice reform.<ref name=legend>{{cite web|title=John Legend talks justice system reform in Sacramento|url=http://www.news10.net/story/life/2015/04/21/john-legend-talks-justice-system-reform-in-sacramento/26104107/|publisher=News10|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> With the help of ARC, Anderson was accepted into [[UCLA]].<ref name=legend /> Anderson has met personally with President [[Barack Obama]].<ref name=guardian>{{cite web|last1=O'Hara|first1=Mary|title=Scott Budnick, Hollywood blockbuster producer, gave it all up to reform prisons|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/jun/20/scott-budnick-hollywood-producer-prison-reform|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref>
== Supporters and funding == [[Robert Downey Jr.]], [[Brent Bolthouse]], [[Dede Gardner]], [[Jake Gyllenhaal]], [[Hill Harper]], [[Bruce Karatz]], and [[Damon Lindelof]], among others, serve on the board of directors.<ref name=board>{{cite web|title=ARC Board of Directors|website=Anti-Recidivism Coalition |url=http://www.antirecidivism.org/board_of_directors|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=sunday>{{cite web|last1=Katz|first1=Jesse|title=Outside Man|url=https://stories.californiasunday.com/2015-03-01/scott-budnick-prison-reform|publisher=California Sunday|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref> Major donors have included the [[California Endowment]], the California Wellness Foundation and the [[Conrad N. Hilton Foundation]].<ref name=times /> [[Ben Lear]], [[Common (rapper)|Common]], [[Jonah Hill]], [[Mike Tollin]], [[Nasir Jones]], [[Raul Ruiz (politician)|Raul Ruiz]], [[Tony Cardenas]], and [[Zach Galifianakis]], among others, serve on ARC's Advisory Board.<ref>{{cite web|title=Advisory Board |website=Anti-Recidivism Coalition|url=http://www.antirecidivism.org/advisory_board|accessdate=2 June 2015}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|40em}}
== Further reading == {{refbegin}} * {{cite web |author=Staff writer |title=This is the Beginning: An Interview with William Lopez of the Anti-Recidivism Coalition |website=Juvenile Justice Information Exchange |date=3 January 2014 |url=https://jjie.org/2014/01/03/this-is-the-beginning-an-interview-with-william-lopez-of-the-anti-recidivism-coalition/ |access-date=27 July 2018}} * {{cite web |last=Budnick |first=Scott |date=12 April 2018 |title=From the Hangover movies to Juvenile Justice Reform |publisher=Juvenile Justice Information Exchange |via=YouTube |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AJi_Essovf0 |access-date=27 July 2018}} * {{cite news |last=Budnick |first=Scott |title=At California's Formidable Ironwood State Prison, Something Extraordinary Is Happening |website=HuffPost |date=3 June 2014 |url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/scott-budnick/something-extraordinary-i_b_5438191.html |access-date=27 July 2018}} * {{cite news |date=8 March 2015 |title=No Joke: Hollywood Comedy Producer Finds Career In Prison Reform |work=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/2015/03/08/388688502/hollywood-producer-finds-unlikely-second-career-prison-reform |access-date=27 July 2018}} * {{cite web |author=Kent G. Mendoza Morales |date=9 April 2014 |title=From Gangs and Gladiator School to the LA Chamber of Commerce |website=Anti-Recidivism Coalition |url=http://www.antirecidivism.org/arc-blog/2015/3/31/from-gangs-and-gladiator-school-to-the-la-chamber-of-commerce |access-date=27 July 2018}} {{refend}}

{{Infobox person | name = Benazir Salam | image = Benazir Salam.JPG | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1979|1|17}} | birth_place = [[Rajshahi]], [[Bangladesh]] | occupation = [[Dancer]], dance teacher | yearsactive = 1983 – present | spouse = {{marriage|[[Dewan Abdullah Zaman]]|1996}} | parents = [[Md. Abdus Salam]]
[[Kohinoor Salam]] | othername = Sumi }} [[Image:Benazir Salam2.JPG|thumb|Benazir Salam]] '''Benazir Salam''' is an [[Indian classical dance]]r from [[Bangladesh]]. == Career == Benazir is the daughter of Md. Abdus Salam and Kohinoor Salam. She began her dance career at the dance school of ''Abdul Hasib Panna'' called ''Nikkon Shilpi Goshthi'' in 1983 in [[Rajshahi]], [[Bangladesh]]. She was considered the national child of the years 1986, 1988 and 1989 through a competition organized by the [[Shishu Academy]] of [[Bangladesh]]. In those competitions she performed [[Kathak]], [[Bharatanatyam]], [[Modern Dance]] and [[Folk Dance]]. She was awarded gold medals in [[Manipuri dance]], Modern Dance and Katthak Dance in Dhaka Junior Art and Music Festival 1988, sponsored by [[British Council]] and [[ANZ Grindlays Bank]]. She won the first Prize in Classical Dance (Katthak) in the National Education Week, [[Dhaka]], Bangladesh in 1990. She also won [[UNESCO]] Clubs Cultural Award, Bangladesh in the same year. She received a scholarship from the [[Indian Council for Cultural Relations]]http://www.iccrindia.org/ (ICCR) for her undergraduate (honors) degree in [[Odissi]] from [[Rabindra Bharati University]] between 1996 and 1999. She secured the first position among her class and received the university gold medal. Benazir subsequently completed her masters in Odissi dance from the university securing the first position and the gold medal. During her stay at the university, she was a disciple of renowned dancer Muralidhar Majhi and Poushali Mukherjee. Currently she teaches Odissi dance at her own school in Bangladesh, ''Nupur''.Deepita, Novera. "Benazir: a Promising Odissi Dancer." The Daily Star 30 January 2005. Accessed 10 September 2008 [http://www.thedailystar.net/2005/01/30/d50130140295.htm]. She also is a dance teacher at Bangladesh Shishu Academy in [[Dhaka]]."Alumni/Data Bank of ICCR Scholarship holders from Bangladesh." Accessed 10 September 2008 [http://www.hcidhaka.org/ICCR%20SCHOLAR%20ALUMNI%20DATA.doc]. == References == {{Reflist}} {{Commons category}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Salam, Benazir}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1979 births]] [[Category:Bangladeshi female dancers]] [[Category:Dance teachers]] [[Category:Rabindra Bharati University alumni]] [[Category:Odissi dancers]] [[Category:Performers of Indian classical dance]] [[Category:Bangladeshi choreographers]] {{dance-bio-stub}}

[[File:Carbon snake2.jpg|thumb|A column of porous graphite formed during the experiment.]] [[File:Carbonsnake.webm|thumb|Carbon snake experiment]]
'''Carbon snake''' is a demonstration of the [[dehydration reaction]] of [[sugar]] by concentrated [[sulfuric acid]]. With concentrated sulfuric acid, granulated table sugar ([[sucrose]]) performs degradation reaction which changes its form to black solid-liquid [[mixture]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Chemical Demonstrations a handbook for teachers of chemistry volume 1|last=Shakhashiri|first=Bassam Z.|last2=Shreiner|first2=Rodney|last3=Bell|first3=Jerry A.|publisher=University of Wisconsin press|year=2011|isbn=978-0-299-08890-3|location=|pages=77-78|chapter=1.32 Dehydration of Sugar by Sulfuric Acid}}</ref> Carbon snake experiment can sometimes be misrecognized as [[Black snake (firework)|black snake]], "sugar snake," or "burning sugar", which involve the reaction with [[Sodium bicarbonate|baking soda]] instead of sulfuric acid.
== Explanation ==
Concentrated sulfuric acid can perform a dehydration reaction with [[table sugar]]. After mixing, the color changes from white to brownish and eventually to black. The expansion of the mixture is the result of [[vaporization]] of [[water]] and [[Carbon dioxide|CO<sub>2</sub>]] inside the container. The gases inflate the mixture to form a snake-like shape, and give off a burned sugar smell.<ref name=":0" /> The [[granularity]] of the sugar can greatly affect the reaction: powdered sugar reacts very quickly but sugar cubes take longer to react.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zg9wmU7Z-6s Don't Try This at Home - 3 - Sulfuric Acid and Sugar]</ref>
When sucrose gets dehydrated, heat is given out to the surroundings in an [[exothermic reaction]], while [[graphite]] and liquid water are produced by the decomposition of the sugar:<ref>{{Cite book|title=Spectacular Chemical Experiment|last=Roesky|first=Herbert W.|publisher=Wiley|year=2007|isbn=978-3-527-31865-0|location=|pages=17|chapter=Experiment 6: Sugar coal by splitting off water from sugar with sulfuric acid}}</ref>
:C<sub>12</sub>H<sub>22</sub>O<sub>11</sub> {{sub|({{serif|s}})}} + H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> {{sub|({{serif|aq}})}} + 1/2 O<sub>2</sub> {{sub|({{serif|g}})}} → 11 C {{sub|({{serif|s}})}} + CO<sub>2</sub> {{sub|({{serif|g}})}} + 12 H<sub>2</sub>O {{sub|({{serif|g}})}} + SO<sub>2</sub> {{sub|({{serif|g}})}}
As the acid dehydrates the sucrose, the water produced will dilute the sulfuric acid, giving out energy in the form of heat.
:C<sub>12</sub>H<sub>22</sub>O<sub>11</sub> {{sub|({{serif|s}})}} → 12 C {{sub|({{serif|s}})}} + 11 H<sub>2</sub>O {{sub|({{serif|l}})}}
== Alternative experiment ==
[[Paranitroaniline]] can be used instead of sugar.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Chemical Demonstrations: A Sourcebook for Teachers Volume 1|last=Summerlin|first=Lee R.|last2=Ealy|first2=James L.|publisher=American Chemical Society|year=1988|isbn=978-0-841-21481-1|edition=2nd|location=|pages=171|chapter=Experiment 100: Dehydration of p-Nitroaniline: Sanke and Puff}}</ref> It takes longer time for a black snake to develop and it requires heating under [[fumehood]], but once formed, the black snake rises from the container very rapidly.<ref>[https://communities.acs.org/thread/6242 Carbon Snake: demonstrating the dehydration power of concentrated sulfuric acid]</ref> It may lead to [[explosion]] if too much sulfuric acid is used.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YKHUnHDphTc How to make P-Nitroaniline]</ref>
== See also == * [[Elephant's toothpaste]] * [[Black snake (firework)]] * [[Diet Coke and Mentos eruption]]
== References == <references />
== External links == {{commonscat|Carbon snake}} * [https://www.chemedx.org/video/dehydration-sucrose-sulfuric-acid Dehydration of sucrose with sulfuric acid] ChemEd X * [https://melscience.com/en/experiments/sugar-snake/ Sugar snake (Sugar and Baking soda)] MEL science * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nqDHwd9rG0s Sugar Snake: Sulfuric Acid and Sugar] youtube.com
[[Category:Chemistry classroom experiments]]

[[File:Charles Proteus Steinmetz.jpg|thumb|upright|Steinmetz circa 1915]]
The '''Charles Proteus Steinmetz Memorial Lecture''' is a series of academic lectures initiated in 1925<ref>[https://www.union.edu/news/stories/2015/04/prominent-woman-engineer-to-headline-steinmetz-memorial-lecture.php Steinmetz Memorial Lecture]</ref> in honor of celebrated mathematician and electrical engineer [[Charles Proteus Steinmetz]]. To date seventy three addresses have been given on subjects ranging from [[peace]]<ref>[https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?arnumber=6436246 ''Cooperation Versus War'', Comfort A. Adams, IEEE Institute Activities, April 1942]</ref> and [[educational reform]]<ref>[https://www.ieeexplore.ieee.org "The Great Reappraisal of Public Education", H. L. Caswell of Columbia university gives 24th Steinmetz Memorial Lecture, IEEE News, May 24, 1952]</ref> to [[nanotechnology]]<ref>[https://www.union.edu/news/stories/2012/05/mildred-dresselhaus-to-give-72nd-steinmetz-lecture-may-1.php “The Promise of Nanomaterials for Thermoelectric Applications,” Mildred Dresselhaus (2012), Union College News Stories, May 2012]</ref> and [[solar photovoltaics]].<ref>[https://muse.union.edu/newsarchives/category/stories/page/119/ "Solar Photovoltaics Technology: The Beginning of the Revolution", Lawrence A. Kazmerski (2009), Union College News Archives, April 2009]</ref>
The seventy-fourth, "The Evolution of the Smart Grid from Edison and Steinmetz", was delivered by Dr. Anjan Bose, Regents Professor at [[Washington State University]], on October 2, 2018.<ref name=bose>[https://www.eventbrite.com/e/74th-steinmetz-memorial-lecture-tickets-45933972749 The Steinmetz Memorial Lecture for 2018]</ref> It was hosted by [[Union College]] and is open to the general public.
==History== [[File:Albert Einstein with other engineers and scientists at Marconi RCA radio station 1921.jpg|thumb|Group being given a tour of the [[Marconi wireless|Marconi Wireless Station]] in Somerset, New Jersey, in 1921, Steinmetz (center), [[Albert Einstein]] (to his right)]]
Shortly after Steinmetz's death at 58 in 1923, his friends and admirers, including prominent figures at [[General Electric]] in [[Schenectady, New York]], endowed the series. It is overseen by the Schenectady Section of the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]]<ref name=ieeehist>[http://ethw.org/IEEE_Schenectady_Section_History IEEE Schenectady Section History]</ref> and hosted by [[Union College]], where Steinmetz long held a professorship. Among those receiving the honor of delivering the lecture have been such notables as [[Nobel Prize|Nobel laureate]] experimental physicist [[Robert A. Millikan]] (1927), helicopter inventor [[Igor Sikorsky]] (1938), nuclear submarine pioneer [[Hyman G. Rickover|Admiral Hyman G. Rickover]] (1963), Nobel-winning [[semiconductor]] inventor [[William Shockley]] (1966), and Internet 'founding father' [[Leonard Kleinrock]] (2010).<ref name=lecturers>[https://users.math.yale.edu/~bbm3/web_docs/steinmetz.doc Dr. Charles Proteus Steinmetz Memorial Lecture Series]</ref>
==Honorees== [[File:Union College Nott.jpg|thumb|[[Union College]], host of the lecture series]]
The featured lecturers of the Steinmetz series have included:<ref name=lecturers/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://muse.union.edu/ecbe/news-events/steinmetz-memorial-lecture/ |title=Steinmetz Memorial Lecture |website=[[Union College]] |accessdate=November 4, 2018}}</ref> * 1 – [[Mihajlo Pupin|Mihajlo I. Pupin]] (1925) * 2 – [[Ernst Julius Berg|Ernst J. Berg]] (1926) * 3 – [[Robert A. Millikan]] (1927) * 4 – [[Max Mason]] (1928) * 5 – [[Dexter S. Kimball]] (1929) * 6 – [[William E. Wickenden]] (1930) * 7 – [[Karl T. Compton]] (1932) * 8 – [[C. E. Kenneth Mees]] (1934) * 9 – [[Robert E. Doherty]] (1935) * 10 – [[Gerard Swope]] (1936) * 11 – [[Harold G. Moulton]] (1937) * 12 – [[Igor I. Sikorsky]] (1938) * 13 – [[Frank B. Jewett]] (1939) * 14 – [[Frank Howard Lahey]] (1941) * 15 – [[Comfort A. Adams|Comfort A. Adams]] (1942) * 16 – [[Harold W. Dodds|Harold Willis Dodds]] (1943) * 17 – [[Stephen S. Wise]] (1944) * 18 – [[Irving Langmuir]] (1945) * 19 – [[Sanford A. Moss]] (1946) * 20 – [[Arthur H. Compton]] (1947) * 21 – [[Philip Sporn]] (1948) * 22 – [[Kirtley F. Mather]] (1949) * 23 – [[Charles Erwin Wilson|Charles E. Wilson]] (1950) * 24 – [[Hollis L. Caswell]] (1952) * 25 – [[Harold S. Osborne]] (1953) * 26 – [[Charles Allen Thomas|Charles A. Thomas]] (1954) * 27 – [[G. Bromley Oxnam|Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam]] (1955) * 28 – [[Cornelius P. Rhoads|Cornelius Packard Rhodes]] (1956) * 29 – [[William Fechteler|Admiral William Morrow Fechteler, Ph.D.]] (1957) * 30 – [[Joseph Allen Hynek]] (1958) * 31 – [[Simon Ramo]] (1959) * 32 – [[Lillian M. Erik Jonsson]] (1969) * 41 – [[Lelan F. Sillin, Jr.]] (1970) * 42 – [[Patrick E. Haggerty]] 1971) * 43 – [[Harold W. Bibber]], Emil J. Remscheid, & Joseph S. Hayden (1972) * 44 – [[John Bardeen]] (1973) * 45 – [[Richard W. Roberts]] (1975) * 46 – [[Jay W. Forrester]] (1976) * 47 – [[Hans A. Schmitt]] (1984) * 53 – [[Erich Bloch]] (1985) * 54 – [[Ivar Giaever]] (1986) * 55 – [[Ernest L. Boyer]] (1987) * 56 – [[Benoit B. Mandelbrot]] (1988) * 57 – [[Robert M. revision.text:
There are a dozen major music conservatories in [[Morocco]], supported by the Ministry of Culture. Some of the larger of these institutions use French names in international correspondence.<ref>International who's who in music and musicians' directory: Page 845 David M. Cummings - 2000 "Casablanca, Conservatory de Musique. Marrakesh. Ecole Nationale de Musique. 22 Rue Marrakchia. Kaa Ouarda. Meknes. Conservatoire National de Musique, de Danse, et d'Art Dramatique, Rabat. Conservatoire de Tangier. Tanger.</ref>
* Conservatoire National de Musique, de Danse, et d'Art Dramatique, Rabat - The National Institute for Music and Dance, [[Rabat]] (المعهد الوطني للموسيقى و الرقص بالرباط) is the most prestigious of the conservatories, established in 1944, and today has around 2000 students enrolled. * The Domestic Music Institute in [[Rabat]] (المعهد الموسيقي دار مولاي رشيد بالرباط), established 1928, at Dar Moulay Rachid Sidi Fateh, with 100 students. * Conservatory of Salé (المعهد الموسيقي بسلا), [[Salé]] established 1995, with around 1000 students. * Conservatory of Kenitra (المعهد الموسيقي بالقنيطرة), [[Kenitra]] established 1968, with 300 students. * Music Institute (المعهد الموسيقي بفاس), [[Fes|Fez]] established 1960, 400 students. * Conservatory House Adeel (المعهد الموسيقي دار عديل فاس) Fez, 2001, 100 students. * Conservatory of Casablanca (المعهد الموسيقي بالدار البيضاء), [[Casablanca]], 1973, 200 students. * Conservatory of Tetuan (المعهد الموسيقي بتطوان), [[Tetouan]], 1945, 500 students enrolled. * Conservatory of Tangier (المعهد الموسيقي بطنجة), [[Tangier]], established 1962, 10 Rue Mahatma Gandhi, 450 students, specialising in [[Andalusi music]] and with the [[Orchestra of Tangier]]. Alumni include the singer [[Mohammed El-Arabi Serghini]]. * Conservatory of Larache (المعهد الموسيقي بالعرائش) [[Larache]], 1972, 300 students. * Conservatory of Chefchaoun (المعهد الموسيقي بشفشاون) [[Chefchaouen]], 1976, 200 students. * Conservatory of the Grand Palace (المعهد الموسيقي بالقصر الكبير) founded 1972, 300 students. * Conservatory of Marrakech (المعهد الموسيقي بمراكش), [[Marrakech]]. 1948, 500 students. * Conservatory of Meknes (المعهد الموسيقي بمكناس), [[Meknes]], 1966, 350 students. * Conservatory of Agadir (المعهد الموسيقي بأكادير), [[Agadir]], 1972, about 650 students. * Conservatory of Taza (المعهد الموسيقي بتازة), [[Fes|Fez]], 1972, 250 students * Conservatory of Oujda (المعهد الموسيقي بوجدة), [[Oujda]], 1992 100 students * Conservatory of Safi (المعهد الموسيقي بأسفي), Qishla 4, Shawki Street [[Safi, Morocco|Safi]], 1968, 200 students * Conservatory of Jerada (المعهد الموسيقي بجرادة), [[Jerada]] 2002, 80 students * Conservatory of Temara (المعهد الموسيقي بتمارة) [[Temara]], 500 students * Conservatory of Sidi Qasim (المعهد الموسيقي بسيدي قاسم) [[Sidi Qasim]], 2004, 150 * Conservatory of Essaouira (المعهد الموسيقي بالصويرة) [[Essaouira]], 100 students * Conservatory Beni Mellal (المعهد الموسيقي ببني ملال) [[Beni Mellal]], 1989, 250 students * Conservatory of Tiznit (المعهد الموسيقي بتيزنيت) [[Agadir]]. 100 students * Conservatory of Khemisset (المعهد الموسيقي بالخميسات) [[Khemisset]], 1985, 350 students * Conservatory of Demnat (المعهد الموسيقي بدمنات) [[Rabat]] 1999, 70 students * Conservatory of Abi J'Aad (المعهد الموسيقي بأبي الجعد) Abi J'Aad, 2010
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Music organizations based in Morocco]] [[Category:Education in Morocco]]

{{Infobox person | image = Danny Antonucci.png | caption = Antonucci at the 2007 Platform Festival. | name = Danny Antonucci | birth_name = Daniel Edward Antonucci | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1957|2|27}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada | residence = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Sheridan College|Sheridan College of Visual Arts]] | yearsactive = 1971–present | known_for = {{plain list| *''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'' *''[[Lupo the Butcher]]'' *''[[The Brothers Grunt]]'' }} | occupation = Animator, director, producer, writer }} '''Daniel Edward Antonucci''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|æ|n|t|ə|ˈ|n|uː|tʃ|i}};{{YouTube|9UZWMlirbRU|"400th Episode Special: Cartoon Network Interview with Danny Antonucci"}} born February 27, 1957) is a Canadian animator, director, producer, and writer. Antonucci is known for creating the [[Cartoon Network]] animated comedy series ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]''. He also created ''[[Lupo the Butcher]]'', ''[[Cartoon Sushi]]'', and ''[[The Brothers Grunt]]''. Antonucci dropped out of the [[Sheridan College|Sheridan College of Visual Arts]] to take a job as an animator at [[Hanna-Barbera]], where he worked on a number of series, including ''[[The Flintstones Comedy Hour]]'', ''[[Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo (1979 TV series)|Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo]]'', ''[[The Smurfs (TV series)|The Smurfs]]'', and ''[[Richie Rich (1980 TV series)|Richie Rich]]''. He continued his career in [[Vancouver, British Columbia|Vancouver]], where he worked on animated shorts and [[television commercials]] for International Rocketship Limited, and created his first solo work, the animated short ''[[Lupo the Butcher]]''. At [[MTV]], he worked on a number of commercials, his series ''[[The Brothers Grunt]]'', and the animation showcase program ''[[Cartoon Sushi]]'', which he co-created with Keith Alcorn. He went on to create ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'' for Cartoon Network. In 2008, Antonucci signed to the now-defunct [[WildBrain]]. Throughout his career, Antonucci won a number of awards. Many of his commercials for [[Converse (shoe company)|Converse]], [[ESPN]] and [[Levi's]] won a number of awards. ''[[Lupo the Butcher]]'' was a successful short and is considered to be a cult classic. ==Early life== Antonucci's parents were [[Italians|Italian]] immigrants to Canada. His experiences as a child in an immigrant family deeply influenced his later work, such as ''Lupo the Butcher''.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Ns5RPHQigg|title=WMX 66 "Interview with Danny Antonucci"|author=Xolo.tv|date=August 25, 2006|access-date=June 21, 2018}} Antonucci attended the [[Sheridan College|Sheridan College of Visual Arts]] but quit to take a job as an animator{{cite web| url =http://www.animationfestival.ca/archives/2006/index.php?option=com_oiaf&task=showevent&i=74&Itemid=433| title =Danny Antonucci| work =[[Ottawa International Animation Festival]]| accessdate =June 19, 2012}} at Canimage Production, a division of [[Hanna-Barbera]].{{cite web| url =http://www.animationmagazine.net/tv/antonucci-makes-toons-with-wldbrain/| title =Antonucci Makes Toons with W!LDBRAIN| first= Ryan| last =Ball| work =[[Animation Magazine]]| date =September 5, 2008| accessdate =May 21, 2012}} ==Career== Starting his career as an animator, Antonucci worked on numerous shows, including ''[[The Flintstones Comedy Hour]]'', ''[[Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo (1979 TV series)|Scooby-Doo and Scrappy-Doo]]'', ''[[The Smurfs (1981 TV series)|The Smurfs]]'', and ''[[Richie Rich (1980 TV series)|Richie Rich]]''.{{cite web| url =http://www.kidzworld.com/article/7993-ed-edd-n-eddy-tv-show-facts#| title =Ed, Edd n Eddy TV Show Facts| work =Kidzworld.com| accessdate =May 28, 2012}} Intending to move to [[Los Angeles]] in 1984 to find more work, Antonucci landed in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. He landed a job at International Rocketship Limited, animating short films and [[television commercials]]. His first effort was on the short film ''Hooray for Sandbox Land''. ===International Rocketship Limited, foundation of a.k.a. Cartoon, and MTV work=== Antonucci's first solo work was ''[[Lupo the Butcher]]'', produced by International Rocketship Limited, about a short-tempered butcher who swears at the meat he is cutting and gets extremely mad at the smallest mistakes. Antonucci says the short arose out of his own frustration at having to work in children's film for so long, and to try his hand at creating a full-fledged character on film. The short animated film screened at several film festivals, including [[Spike and Mike's Sick and Twisted Festival of Animation]] in the [[United States]]. The 'Lupo' character was eventually licensed by the [[Converse (shoe company)|Converse]] athletic shoe company. This led to additional work, including animated commercials for [[Levi Strauss & Co.]] and [[MTV]]. He also originally created bumpers for [[Cartoon Network]] featuring the [[jester]]. On April 1, 1994, Antonucci started an animation company named [[a.k.a. Cartoon]], which produced the short-lived [[MTV]] series ''[[The Brothers Grunt]]'', which began airing in 1994 and ended its run in 1995. Antonucci went on to work on [[MTV]]'s ''[[Cartoon Sushi]]'' show in 1997, directing, writing and providing voices, in addition to being responsible for the title sequence of the show. ===''Ed, Edd n Eddy''=== {{Main|Ed, Edd n Eddy}} Feeling confined to "gross" and "edgy" work, such as his series ''[[The Brothers Grunt]]'', Antonucci decided to produce an animated children's television show again with his company [[a.k.a. Cartoon]]. He resolved, however, to ensure that the series was produced in a way similar to the cartoon styles from the 1940s to the 1970s.{{cite video| people =Danny Antonucci| year = October 10, 2006| title = Ed, Edd n Eddy: The Complete First Season—''Interview with the Creator''| time = 0:22–2:34 | medium = DVD| publisher = [[Warner Home Video]]}} Antonucci spent months designing the show, before trying to sell it to [[Nickelodeon]]. Nickelodeon told him that they would take the show, if they also obtained creative control. Antonucci refused to give it, and instead took the show to [[Cartoon Network]]. A deal was ultimately made for Cartoon Network to commission the show, after they agreed to let Antonucci go in his own direction. Antonucci is a strong advocate of hand-drawn animation. The wobbling animation in ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'' is an homage to the hand-drawn cartoons with a style that harkens back to cartoons of the 1940s to the 1970s. To give the impression of movement, ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'' uses shimmering character outlines similar to ''[[Squigglevision]]''. The crawling lines are not nearly as active as those in ''[[Dr. Katz, Professional Therapist]]'', but are still visible,{{cite news|first=Matt|last=Shumway|author2=Wayne, Lamont|title=Ed, Edd n Eddy: A Unique Approach|date=June 1999|url=http://www.awn.com/mag/issue4.03/4.03pages/SCAD_EEE.php3|work=Animation World Magazine|issue=4.3|accessdate=July 31, 2008}} and Antonucci likens it to cartoons of the 1930s. According to Antonucci, the characters were based on real people in his life. The personalities of Ed, Edd, and Eddy are based on personal traits of himself, and the activities of his two sons.{{cite video| people =Danny Antonucci| year = October 10, 2006| title = Ed, Edd n Eddy: The Complete First Season—''Interview with the Creator''| time = 2:15–4:39 | medium = DVD| publisher = [[Warner Home Video]]}} The Eds also possess personality traits similar to [[The Three Stooges]], whose money-making schemes and antics also invariably backfire.{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/28046/ed-edd-n-eddy-the-complete-second-season/|title=DVD Talk Review: Ed, Edd 'n' Eddy — The Complete Second Season|accessdate=July 31, 2007|last=Cornelius|first=David|date=April 24, 2007|work=[[DVD Talk]]}} The cul-de-sac children and the [[Kanker Sisters]] were all based on children he grew up with. Antonucci also stated that he believed it was important to add Plank, a board of wood, to the show, stating that he "thought it would be really cool to do the show with Plank taking on a character of his own" and to cause Jonny to do things he would usually never do. He also stated that Rolf is strongly based on himself and his cousins, since he was part of an immigrant family, and grew up in a first-generation foreign household with different customs and ways of living. ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'' is the only [[A.k.a. Cartoon]] show to have a theatrical movie based on the animated television series. The series' finale movie, ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy's Big Picture Show]]'', aired on November 8, 2009, officially ending the series.{{cite news|first=Matt|last=Kapko|title=Ed, Edd n Eddy's Big Picture Show Premiers in the U.S.|date=November 16, 2009|url=http://www.awn.com/news/television/ed-edd-n-eddy-s-big-picture-show-premiers-us|work=[[Animation World Network]]|accessdate=April 30, 2011}} However, reruns continued to air on the network until July 1, 2011. On March 30, 2012, the series received another opportunity to air re-runs on the revived block ''[[Cartoon Planet]]''.{{cite web|last=Walton|first=Zach|title=Cartoon Network Brings Back The Classics With Cartoon Planet|url=http://www.webpronews.com/cartoon-network-brings-back-the-classics-with-cartoon-planet-2012-03|publisher=WebProNews|accessdate=March 29, 2012}} ===WildBrain and upcoming series=== While Antonucci was working on ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy's Big Picture Show]]'', it was announced on September 4, 2008 that he signed to [[WildBrain]]; Antonucci stated that he was "already kicking around three different ideas for his first Wildbrain project."{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2008/digital/news/wildbrain-pacts-with-antonucci-1117991652/|title=WildBrain pacts with Antonucci|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[PMC (company)|Penske Media Corporation]]|date=September 4, 2008|accessdate=January 17, 2014}} On June 11, 2013, animator [[Joe Murray (animator)|Joe Murray]] posted a short interview with Antonucci for his class on his website, and on the end wrote: "He's currently working on a new series, so rock on."{{cite web|author=[[Joe Murray (animator)|Joe Murray]]|url=http://joemurraystudio.com/2434/june-11-2013/|title=June 11, 2013|date=June 11, 2013|accessdate=January 17, 2014}} ==Awards and nominations== Antonucci's first solo work ''[[Lupo the Butcher]]'' was a successful short and is considered to be a cult classic. [[Eric Fogel]], creator of ''[[Celebrity Deathmatch]]'', stated that ''[[Lupo the Butcher]]'' "opened [his] eyes to a world of animation that was strictly for grownups and inspired [him] to pursue a career path that was a bit more... twisted".{{cite news|first=Matt|last=Kapko|title=The Toon That Changed My Life|date=February 5, 2010|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/features/the-toon-that-changed-my-life/|work=[[Animation Magazine]]|accessdate=May 17, 2011}} Throughout his career, Antonucci received a number of awards. He worked on a number of award-winning commercials for [[Converse (shoe company)|Converse]], [[ESPN]] and [[Levi's]]. In 1998, for his work on ''[[Cartoon Sushi]]'', Antonucci received a [[National Cartoonists Society Division Awards|National Cartoonists Society Division Award]] for [[National Cartoonists Society Division Awards#Television Animation Award|Television Animation]]. His series ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'' received several awards and nominations; for his work on the series, Antonucci won a [[National Cartoonists Society#Reuben Award|Reuben Award]] for Best Television Animation in 1999{{cite journal|title=Animation World News: Awards|url=http://www.awn.com/mag/issue4.03/4.03pages/4.03awards.php3|work=[[Animation World Network|Animation World Magazine]]|issue=4.3|accessdate=April 30, 2012}} and a [[Leo Awards|Leo Award]] for Best Director in an Animated Production or Series in 2000.{{cite web|title=2000 Winners|url=http://www.leoawards.com/2012/2000_winners.html|work=[[Leo Awards]]|accessdate=May 2, 2012}} He became best known for ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'', which with an almost 11-year run remains the longest running original [[Cartoon Network]] series and Canadian-made animated series to date.{{cite web|title=CN/D3 Unleash New Ed, Edd n Eddy Game|first=Chris|last=Grove|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/article/6990|date=September 5, 2008|work=[[Animation Magazine]]|accessdate=June 16, 2012}} It was also [[Cartoon Network]]'s most popular series among boys ages 2–11.{{cite web|title=Midway Enters Publishing Agreement For 3 Cartoon Network Shows |first=Marc-André |last=Sarrazin |url=http://www.nintendospin.com/news/midway-enters-publishing-agreement-for-3-cartoon-network-shows/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120904151647/http://www.nintendospin.com/news/midway-enters-publishing-agreement-for-3-cartoon-network-shows/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 4, 2012 |date=February 26, 2005 |work=NintendoSpin.com |accessdate=May 26, 2012 }} Bob Higgins, head of [[WildBrain]], considered ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'' to be a "landmark in animation". [[Joe Murray (animator)|Joe Murray]], famous for creating the animated series ''[[Rocko's Modern Life]]'' and ''[[Camp Lazlo]]'', called Antonucci "one of the founders and mainstays of modern animation".{{cite web|author=[[Joe Murray (animator)|Joe Murray]]|url=http://joemurraystudio.com/2434/june-11-2013/|title=June 11, 2013|date=June 11, 2013|accessdate=January 17, 2014}} ==Filmography== ===Films=== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#b0c4de; text-align:center;" ! Year ! Title ! Role |- | 1971 | ''The Adventures of Barfman'' | Short film

Role |- | 1980–82 | ''[[The Richie Rich/Scooby-Doo Show and Scrappy Too!]]'' | Animator |- | 1980–82 | ''[[The Flintstone Comedy Show (1980 TV series)|The Flintstone Comedy Show]]'' | Animator |- | 1981 | ''[[The Smurfs (1981 TV series)|The Smurfs]]'' | Animator |- | 1994–95 | ''[[The Brothers Grunt]]'' | Creator, co-writer, executive producer, director, and voice actor |- | 1997 | ''[[Cartoon Sushi]]'' | Co-creator and director |- | 1999–2009 | ''[[Ed, Edd n Eddy]]'' | Creator, director, executive producer, co-writer, and voice of Mr. Sun from "[[The Eds are Coming, the Eds are Coming]]" |} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|0031495}} {{Danny Antonucci}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Antonucci, Danny}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Artists from Toronto]] [[Category:Canadian animators]] [[Category:Canadian humorists]] [[Category:Canadian storyboard artists]] [[Category:Canadian television directors]] [[Category:Canadian television producers]] [[Category:Canadian television writers]] [[Category:Canadian male voice actors]] [[Category:Film directors from Toronto]] [[Category:Hanna-Barbera people]] [[Category:Danny Antonucci]] [[Category:Reuben Award winners]] [[Category:Sheridan College animation program alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Toronto]]

An '''executive head teacher''', '''executive head master''', '''executive head mistress''', '''executive head''' or '''executive principal''' is the substantive or strategic [[head teacher]] of more than one school in the [[United Kingdom]].
The position role of an executive head teacher usually comes in one of three forms: The appointed executive head is responsible for the management of more than one school. They remain the head teacher of their current school, but also become the strategic leader of one or more other schools. The executive head has no substantive headship in any school but remains the strategic leader of a chain, federation or collaboration of schools. In the case of the third option, the executive head teacher is above the head teachers appointed to manage each individual school within the consortium.
The role of executive heads was first introduced in 2004 when in 1996 the then Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] announced that a new policy would allow head teachers who had been classed as outstanding to take over the leadership of schools who had been designated by local authorities as failing. The idea put forward that once the standards in those failing schools had improved, a new head teacher could take over.<ref>[https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/340000/executive-heads-summary.pdf Executive heads: Summary report] National College </ref> Today however the role and idea of and executive head teacher has expanded, with many staying in place within a system leadership role rather than specific headship roles; working with a number of head teachers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/teacher-network/teacher-blog/2013/jul/09/executive-headteacher-schools-leadership|title=The rise of the executive headteacher|first=Nick|last=Morrison|date=9 July 2013|website=the Guardian}}</ref>

{{more citations needed|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox university | name = FON University | image = FON-university.JPG | image_upright = | image_alt = FON University | caption = FON University Building | latin_name = | established = {{start date and age|2003}} | type = [[Private university|Private]] | rector = [[Nano Ruzin]], PhD | faculty = 170 | staff = 90 | students = 5,300 | city = [[Skopje]], [[Strumica]], [[Struga]] and [[Gostivar]] | country = [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|59|35|N|21|28|28|E|type:edu_source:kolossus-frwiki|display=inline, title}} | campus = Urban | affiliations = | website = {{URL|http://www.fon.edu.mk/}} | logo = FON University logo.jpg | logo_size = | logo_alt = FON University logo }} The '''FON University''' ({{lang-mk|ФОН Универзитет}}) is a private university with headquarters in [[Skopje]], [[Republic of Macedonia]]. It is the second private university established in the [[Republic of Macedonia]], after the liberalization of the High education law's in 2002.<ref>http://fon.edu.mk/content.aspx?ln=en&cid=15</ref> After its establishment great number of professors from the [[Ss. Cyril and Methodius University of Skopje]] transferred to the new university and contributed to building a better educational system in Republic of Macedonia.
Present day the university has grown to 10 faculties with total academic staff of 170, and supporting technical staff of 90 people. The university is the first high education institution in Macedonia that has implemented fully the [[Bologna process|Bologna requirements]], and the [[European Credit Transfer System]]. Total of more than 5,300 students study at the university campus. The University has four campuses based in [[Skopje]], [[Struga]], [[Strumica]] and [[Gostivar]]<ref>http://fon.edu.mk/content.aspx?cid=21&ln=en</ref> on more than 90,000 square meters.
==Faculties== The University has 9 faculties: * Faculty of Law * Faculty of Political Science, Diplomacy and Journalism * Faculty of Applied Foreign Languages * Faculty for Detectives and Security * Faculty of Economics * Faculty of Information and Communication Technology * Faculty of Sport and Sport Management * Faculty of Design and Multimedia * Faculty of Architecture
==Student life== The University has an active [[student body]], which is synchronizing the extra CV activities of the students, organises projects, finds internship for the students, does evaluation of the studies and giving suggestions for their advancement. Organizes student competitions and sports activities, social events and happenings. The student's association publishes a magazine involving all students with journalistic affinities and dealing with issues that concern and interest the students. The students' association also collaborates with the Center for Development and Careers to realize a part of its activities. [[Image:Fon 05.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Ground floor of the University building]]
==See also== * [[Balkan Universities Network]] * [[List of universities in the Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Skopje]]

'''Florence Bell Robinson''' (1885-1973) was born on November 1, 1885 in [[Lapeer, Michigan]]. She was a prominent educator in [[landscape architecture]] and a pioneer in introducing women into the field.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0DZUAAAAMAAJ|title=Architecture and women: a bibliography documenting women architects, landscape architects, designers, architectural critics and writers, and women in related fields working in the United States|last=Doumato|first=Lamia|date=1988-11-01|publisher=Garland Pub.|isbn=9780824041052|language=en}}</ref>
==Life== She received her undergraduate degree in science from [[Kalamazoo College]] in 1908, and the BArch and MID (Master in Landscape Design) in 1924 from the [[University of Michigan]]. She ran her own landscape firm from 1916-1926 and worked as a draftsperson for J.W. Case in Detroit.<ref name="auto">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=02eFrTPIo4gC|title=No Boundaries: University of Illinois Vignettes|last=Hoddeson|first=Lillian|date=2004-01-01|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=9780252072031|language=en}}</ref>
She arrived at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign|University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign]] in 1926 and spent the rest of her career there, developing a highly ranked landscape architecture department with colleagues [[Stanley Hart White|Stanley White]] and Karl Lohmann. In 1926 she was hired as associate teacher, then in 1929 she was hired as the first female tenure track faculty member. In 1949 she was promoted to associate professor, then in 1951 she was made full professor in the Department of Landscape Architecture. She retired in 1953.<ref name="auto1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=drWgBgAAQBAJ|title=Women, Modernity, and Landscape Architecture|last=Dümpelmann|first=Sonja|last2=Beardsley|first2=John|date=2015-02-11|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317556558|language=en}}</ref> In addition to teaching she also maintained her own practice. An expert in the area of plants and planting design, she published and lectured extensively, and developed a plant cataloging system for educating students that was later published.<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yuA4AQAAIAAJ|title=Shaping the American Landscape: New Profiles from the Pioneers of American Landscape Design Project|last=Birnbaum|first=Charles A.|last2=Foell|first2=Stephanie Sue|date=2009-01-01|publisher=University of Virginia Press|isbn=9780813927893|language=en}}</ref> Many of her students went on to play a prominent role in the field of landscape architecture, including [[Hideo Sasaki]], [[Peter Walker (landscape architect)|Peter Walker]], and [[Richard Haag]].<ref name="auto1"/>
==Publications== * Robinson, Florence Bell: Useful Trees and Shrubs (Champaign, IL: Garrard Press, 1938) * Robinson, Florence Bell: Planting Design (New York and London: Whittlesey House, McGraw-Hill Book Co., 1940) * Robinson, Florence Bell: Tabular Keys for the Identification of the Woody Plants (Champaign, IL: Garrard Press, 1941) * Robinson, Florence Bell: Landscape Planting for Airports. (Urbana, Univ. of Illinois, 1948) * Robinson, Florence Bell: Palette of Plants: Sequel to Planting Design (Champaign, IL: Garrard Press, 1950)

{{infobox company | name = Greenwave | logo = Greenwave-logo.jpg | logo_size = 200px }} '''Greenwave''' is a mass [[science]] [[experiment]] involving primary schools across [[Ireland]]. It examines and records how spring arrives in [[Ireland]]. This is an educational and science initiative of the [[Irish Government]]’s [[Discover Science & Engineering]] (DSE) awareness programme.<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/weekend/2008/0202/1201821933083.html Article in The Irish Times]</ref>
Irish students observe and record when certain plants and animals react to the longer days and warmer temperatures, in order to find out whether the "green wave" of spring moves from south to north across [[Ireland]] or inland from the coast to the centre of the country.<ref>[http://www.sligoweekender.ie/news/story/?trs=mhgbauauid Article in the Sligo Weekender]</ref><ref>[http://www.nenaghguardian.ie/news/tipp-schools-take-part-in-experiment-on-spring-season-1288914.html Article in The Guardian]</ref><ref>[http://www.forfas.ie/publications/forfas_annrpt06/developing/dis.html Forfás Annual Report 2006]</ref>
Taking part in Greenwave is a practical way to support the teaching of Social Environmental and Scientific Education (SESE) part of the Irish Primary School Curriculum. The students develop their skills in: *Observing *Classifying *Recognising patterns *Estimating and measuring *Recording and communicating
Schools registered in the [[Discover Primary Science]] programme, another initiative of DSE, can also earn credit towards their Award of Science Excellence by taking part in Greenwave.
DSE runs numerous other initiatives, including [[Science Week Ireland]], [[Discover Primary Science]] and [[Science.ie]].
== References == {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.greenwave.ie Greenwave website] * [http://www.discover-science.ie/programmes-and-audiences/greenwave Information about Greenwave on Discover-Science.ie]

The '''Intern Architect Program''' (IAP), or sometimes the '''Internship in Architecture Program''', is a national program in [[Canada]] that documents and evaluates internship activities, provides structure to the transition between education and registration, and encourages involvement of practitioners in the development of new architects.<ref>{{cite book | last = Hobbs | first = John | title = Canadian Handbook of Practice for Architects | publisher = [[National Practice Program]] for the Profession of Architecture in Canada | date = 1999 | location = Ottawa | pages = 1.1.3 2–3}}</ref> The IAP was established by the [[Committee of Canadian Architectural Councils]] (CCAC), which is composed of representatives from each of the ten provincial associations of architects.
==See also== *[[Architect]]
==References== {{Reflist}}<!--added above External links/Sources by script-assisted edit-->
==External links== *[http://www.raic.org/interns_students/internship/index_e.htm The Internship in Architecture Program (IAP) website]
